<ROOT> <TEXT> <PHI TYPE="ID xxxxSSNxxxx PHI> <PHI TYPE="HOSPITAL">FIH</PHI> Discharge Summary Unsigned DIS Report Status : Unsigned DISCHARGE DATE : <PHI TYPE="DATE xxxxDATE4xxxx PHI>/94 ADMISSION DIAGNOSIS : Aspiration pneumonia , esophageal laceration . HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS : He was transferred to the <PHI TYPE="HOSPITAL">Valtawnprinceel Community xxxHOSPITALxxx Hospital</PHI> for endoscopy and esophagoscopy on the <PHI TYPE="DATE xxxxDATE16xxxx /PHI> which showed a 2 cm linear tear of the esophagus at 30 to 32 cm . The patient 's hematocrit was xxxPEOPLExxx and he was given no further intervention . On the morning of the <PHI TYPE="DATE">22nd</PHI> the patient developed tachypnea with a chest X xxxPEOPLExxx showing a question of congestive heart failure . A medical consult was obtained at the <PHI TYPE="HOSPITAL">Valtawnprinceel Community xxxHOSPITALxxx Hospital</PHI> . A arterial blood gases on 100 percent face mask showed an oxygen of 205 , CO2 57 and PH 7 xxxxADDRESS8xxxx patient 's past medical history is significant for : 2. non insulin dependent diabetes mellitus , 3. history of colitis . 5. blindness . The patient 's medications on transfer are Mucomist and Albuterol nebs , Versed , Morphine prn , D5 half normal at 125 cc per hour , Clindamycin 600 q. 8 hours , Micronase 5 b.i.d. , CZI sliding scale , Cimetidine 300 intravenously q. 8 , Carafate 1 gram per G tube q. 8 hours , Ranitidine 50 mg intravenously q. 6 , Isordil 5 mg q . He is a retired welder . Blood pressure 150/60 , heart rate 90 's , respirations xxxxADDRESS8xxxx fundus was poorly xxxPEOPLExxx He did count fingers in both eyes at one foot . He had 2+ carotids on time without bruits . The jugular venous pressure was xxxxADDRESS8xxxx had diffuse rhonchi and upper airway noises . He had guaiac positive brown stool with a normal prostate . His neurological examination was remarkable for a mildly encephalopathic male . He thought he was in " <PHI TYPE="HOSPITAL">Em Nysonken Medical Center</PHI> " . A chest X xxxPEOPLExxx showed bilateral opacities in the bases with increased interstitial markings . No heparin was given because of his esophageal laceration . No beta blocker was given because of his history of chronic obstructive pulmonary disease . His blood gas at that time on 40 percent face mask was 84 , 42 , 7 xxxxADDRESS8xxxx patient did well on the floor initially with improvement in his arterial blood gases and mental status . He was taken for esophagogastroduodenoscopy by the Surgical Service after elective intubation for airway control . There was no lesion noted in the stomach . The scope was retroflexed in the antrum where it showed a normal fundus of the stomach and normal esophagogastric junction . It was felt the patient 's GI bleeding was secondary to his previously known esophageal tear . He was continued on the intravenous Cimetidine and Carafate except that he was made NPO . He was intubated for airway protection . An electrocardiogram at that time showed a xxxPEOPLExxx rate related xxxPEOPLExxx bundle and apical ST changes consistent with ischemia . On the <PHI TYPE="DATE">26th</PHI> , because of continued massive bleeding , he was taken by Vascular Radiology for a question of embolization . Three sites of active extravasation were found , one from the gastroesophageal junction area and two from the gastric fundus . All sites were successfully embolized with Gelfoam with non selective arterial embolization of the spleen occurring as well . Severe xxxPEOPLExxx external iliac stenosis was noted . He was continued to be managed with packed red blood cells , platelets and fresh frozen plasma . He was continued to be intubated with xxxPEOPLExxx mental status . He was paralyzed for the vascular procedure . A head computerized tomography scan on the <PHI TYPE="DATE">26th</PHI> showed a probable xxxPEOPLExxx cerebellar infarct and a question of a xxxPEOPLExxx middle cerebral artery infarct . No cardiopulmonary resuscitation was performed as per the patient and family wishes . <PHI TYPE="DOCTOR">ZIE M. Hypercholesterolemia . HISTORY / REASON FOR HOSPITALIZATION : The patient is a xxxxAGE5xxxx who presents for an elective scheduled liver resection for metastatic rectal cancer . He underwent preoperative radiation therapy with 5-FU . In <PHI TYPE="DATE xxxxMONTHxxxx PHI> xxxxYEAR_CENTURYxxxx , the patient underwent an APR with excision of liver nodule , intraoperative radiation therapy , and pelvic omentoplasty with descending colostomy by Dr. <PHI TYPE="DOCTOR">Berger</PHI> . The patient received postoperative chemotherapy with 5-FU and Leucovorin . The patient is status post four cycles of HAI FUDR and5-FU with last dose being <PHI TYPE="DATE xxxxDATE21xxxx PHI xxxxADDRESS8xxxx MRI suggests that the liver metastases have become smaller . Significant for metastatic rectal cancer as above . Hypercholesterolemia . Mandibular reconstruction in the APR , insertion of hepatic infusion pump with a cholecystectomy . Zestril 10 mg q.d. , aspirin 81 mg q.d. , Ranitidine 150 mgq .d. and multivitamin q.d. No known drug allergies . PHYSICAL EXAMINATION : She had 98% 02 saturation on room air . On exam , he was well developed , well nourished with good range of motion of his head and neck without masses . His chest was clear to auscultation on both sides . Extremities : No clubbing , cyanosis , or edema . On <PHI TYPE="DATE xxxxDATE4xxxx PHI>/02 , the patient underwent a left hepatectomy andcaudate lobe resection as well as a xxxPEOPLExxx resection of segment 5 and 6. <PHI TYPE="HOSPITAL">HLGMC</PHI> <PHI TYPE="DATE xxxxDATE4xxxx PHI xxxxYEAR_CENTURYxxxx 12:00:00 AM ACUTE POLYMICROBIAL BACTERIAL ENDOCARDITIS . Report Status : Unsigned ADMISSION DATE : <PHI TYPE="DATE">07-26</PHI>-93 DISCHARGED TO <PHI TYPE="HOSPITAL">SOUTHOBASSKING'S VILLEMARG HOSPITAL</PHI> . <PHI TYPE="DATE xxxxDATE21xxxx PHI>/93 - mitral valve replacement and replacement of ascending aorta . OTHER PROCEDURES : HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS : There were transient mental status changes but no convulsions or loss of consciousness . Blood cultures drawn on admission showed multiple organisms including Clostridium perfringens , coagulase negative Staph , and alpha hemolytic Streptococcus . HOSPITAL COURSE : Her antibiotics were appropriately adjusted because of the polymicrobial nature . Cardiac echo showed that she had moderate mitral regurgitation , an enlarged left atrium , and good ventricular function . There was a suggestion of mitral valve vegetation . She was placed on intravenous antibiotics with gradual decrease in her temperature , although some low grade temperatures initially persisted . She was evaluated by the Gynecology Service including the performance of a pelvic ultrasound and also by the GI Service where she underwent a barium enema . She had a cerebral magnetic resonance imaging study performed and there was evidence of stroke . On <PHI TYPE="DATE xxxxDATE21xxxx PHI> , she developed a sudden episode of pulmonary edema that resolved quickly and she was thought to have possible worsening of her mitral regurgitation . Her cardiac catheterization demonstrated minor coronary artery disease and severe mitral regurgitation with a suggestion of an annular abscess . After considerable discussion among the physicians involved in the patient 's care , it had become apparent that the mitral regurgitation had worsened . It was possible to clean the area thoroughly and it also became apparent that there was evidence of calcification in and around the annulus consistent with prior rheumatic fever . Her valve was replaced with a St. xxxNAMExxx Medical mitral prosthesis and it was possible to place the valve securely . She was bleeding after operation with her picture also consistent with coagulopathy , and the overall picture suggested the effects of systemic sepsis . In the early postoperative period , she had evidence of tamponade , possibly related to compression from her lungs , as the patient was noted to have elevated inspiratory pressures on the ventilator . The sternum was reopened with improvement in her hemodynamics and additional stability . Her sternum was left opened and the skin wound was left opened , using an elastic membrane to close the chest . With clotting xxxPEOPLExxx replacement , bleeding gradually abated and was no longer a problem . She remained on full support in the Intensive Care Unit , on dialysis , with ongoing evidence of acidosis . Autopsy permission was granted . <TEXT> <PHI TYPE="ID xxxxSUSPICIOUS_NUMxxxx PHI> <PHI TYPE="ID xxxxSUSPICIOUS_NUMxxxx PHI> <PHI TYPE="DATE xxxxDATE4xxxx PHI xxxxYEAR_CENTURYxxxx 12:00:00 AM SMALL BOWEL OBSTRUCTION DIS Admission Date : Signed Discharge Date : <PHI TYPE="DATE xxxxDATE4xxxx PHI xxxxYEAR_CENTURYxxxx DEATH SUMMARY PRINCIPAL DIAGNOSIS : This is a xxxxAGE5xxxx gentleman with a past medical history of gastric lymphoma status post total gastrectomy / splenectomy in xxxxYEAR_CENTURYxxxx with a Roux en-Y reconstruction . He had a normal bowel movement the day prior to admission . History of small bowel obstruction in <PHI TYPE="DATE xxxxDATE4xxxx PHI> and <PHI TYPE="DATE xxxxDATE4xxxx PHI> , pancytopenia , history of xxxPEOPLExxx renal calculus . Splenectomy , total gastrectomy as above , for gastric lymphoma for which he also received chemotherapy . MEDICATIONS ON ADMISSION : Epogen and Vitamin B 12 injections . ALLERGIES : No known drug allergies . LABORATORY DATA ON ADMISSION : PHYSICAL EXAM : ABDOMEN : No hernias . The patient did have xxxPEOPLExxx costovertebral angle tenderness , decreased bowel sounds . HOSPITAL COURSE : The patient was admitted after placement of a nasogastric tube and was brought emergently to the operating room after a CT scan done in the emergency room revealed marked dilatation of the afferent loop and duodenum . There was significant dilatation from the duodenal stump to the proximal jejunum and an abrupt transition point prior to the likely anastomosis . The patient went to the operating room on the evening of <PHI TYPE="DATE xxxxDATE4xxxx PHI>/00 and after extensive lysis of adhesions , the Roux en-Y anastomosis of jejunum to jejunum was examined and there was found to be a slightly proximal adhesion compressing the afferent limb . This was taken down and the Roux en-Y anastomosis was re sited proximally . There was no other obvious finding on the initial exploratory laparotomy and the peritoneal fluid that was encountered appeared just ascitic in nature . Postoperatively , the patient was tachycardic and had low urine output which initially was responsive to intravenous boluses of Crystalloid . However by the mid morning of the <PHI TYPE="DATE xxxxDATE16xxxx /PHI> , the patient had ceased making urine and had become profoundly tachycardic . The patient was invasively lined with a Swan Ganz catheter and arterial line and was transferred to the intensive care unit . The transesophageal echocardiogram revealed essentially normal left ventricular function but was a very limited exam . On <PHI TYPE="DATE xxxxDATE4xxxx PHI>/00 the patient returned to the operating room for exploratory laparotomy after pressors and antibiotics did not reverse his septic course . However prior to this it was also noted that the patient 's scrotum was necrotic . The anastomosis appeared intact on examination . Upon return to the intensive care unit following this procedure , the patient still had a septic like picture and was maintained on Neo Synephrine . It should be noted that in addition to the afore mentioned duodenal perforation , the patient also was noted to have a pancreatitis by enzymes . This was thought to be related to the back pressure in the afferent limb and this resolve over the course of his immediate postoperative days . The patient 's urine output was marginal and the sepsis appeared not to be well controlled . therefore the patient went back to the operating room on <PHI TYPE="DATE xxxxDATE4xxxx PHI>/00 for another exploratory laparotomy . The patient was washed out and an ileocecectomy for necrotic appearing bowel was performed . On <PHI TYPE="DATE xxxxDATE4xxxx PHI>/00 the patient had a completion colectomy and partial proctatectomy in the bed in the intensive care unit as a last ditch attempt to gain the upper hand on the septic physiology . This progressed inexorably until he developed massive ascites and marked hyperbilirubinemia . Multiple abdominal ultrasound revealed no biliary dilatation ; there was evidence of gallbladder polyps versus stones on one ultrasound . 3. Clinical progression of skin and sinus infection on maximal antimicrobial therapy continued , with emergence on <PHI TYPE="DATE xxxxDATE7xxxx PHI> of a new xxxPEOPLExxx sided ptosis in association with a left homonymous hemianopsia , and fleeting confusion while febrile , prompting head MRI which revealed a large 5 x 2 x 4.3 cm region in the xxxPEOPLExxx occipital lobe of hemorrhage and edema , with dural and , likely , leptomeningeal enhancement in association with small foci in the xxxPEOPLExxx cerebellum and pons , concerning for early lesions of similar type . A single blood culture positive for coagulase negative Staphylococcus was treated with a course of vancomycin in the setting of a PICC line and a chest x xxxPEOPLExxx on <PHI TYPE="DATE xxxxDATE7xxxx PHI> indicating possible developing pneumonia , resulted in a course of levofloxacin , for both possible pneumonia , as well as treatment of any bacterial superinfection of Acanthamoeba sinusitis . Patient experienced steady decline , with persistent fevers despite all above measures , progressive areas of skin infection , more frequent episodes of confusion , and decreasing oxygen saturation in the setting of bilateral effusion , in the setting of fluid surge spacing . On <PHI TYPE="DATE xxxxDATE7xxxx PHI> , a family meeting with patient 's daughter and spouse , along with primary oncologist , Dr. <PHI TYPE="DOCTOR">Tomedankell Bile</PHI> , attending physician , Dr. <PHI TYPE="DOCTOR">Mellerny Close</PHI> , and house staff , was held to discuss patient 's critical condition and inability to prevent progression of skin , sinus and neurological Acanthamoeba infection on maximal antimicrobial therapy . Pentamidine , itraconazole , Levaquin , acyclovir and GCSF were discontinued , along with other medications nonessential to patient 's comfort . The patient was made comfortable with morphine for pain and for air hunger , and sinus suctioning was continued to relieve congestion , in conjunction with continuation of nasal sprays . Tylenol was continued to control fevers and prednisone was continued to control inflammation and prevent precipitation of adrenal insufficiency . Such measures have been continued through <PHI TYPE="DATE xxxxDATE7xxxx PHI> , and patient remains comfortable through this time . <RECORD ID="823"> <TEXT> <PHI TYPE="HOSPITAL">CTMC</PHI> <PHI TYPE="DATE xxxxDATE22xxxx PHI xxxxYEAR_CENTURYxxxx 12:00:00 AM DIS Report Status : Unsigned CHIEF COMPLAINT : HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS : This is an xxxxAGE5xxxx white female who is otherwise healthy by history and presented with a several day history of upper respiratory infection . Of note , the patient does not smoke and does not drink . He recommended that she see a local otolaryngologist . There was also a question of a carcinomatous lesion on the left side of the epiglottis . The patient 's granddaughter , however , works at <PHI TYPE="HOSPITAL">Retelk County Medical Center</PHI> and therefore the family elected to bring the patient xxxPEOPLExxx and then bring her to <PHI TYPE="HOSPITAL">Retelk County Medical Center</PHI> . She presented to the Emergency Room with some throat discomfort , some mild hoarseness , which she said had been progressing over the last few days . ENT examination was then to be performed . Chest x xxxPEOPLExxx showed significant kiphosis but otherwise no significant lesions at all . PAST MEDICAL HISTORY : PAST SURGICAL HISTORY : Negative . MEDICATIONS ON ADMIT : Smoking none . SOCIAL HISTORY : Lives in an old age facility but is quite active and quite independent . PHYSICAL EXAMINATION : She had no respiratory distress but did choose to sit in an upright position . Her ear examination was normal . Nasal examination was normal . Oral cavity was normal . Revealed fullness in the submental and suprahyoid regions with mild tenderness which was consistent with edema of the soft tissues without significant xxxPEOPLExxx Neck : The xxxPEOPLExxx pyriform was narrowed by edema . The epiglottis was so edematous that is was pushed back posteriorly and abutted the posterior oropharynx completely obscuring the larynx . The patient had no stridor and it was clear that she must be breathing around the epiglottis . There was blood oozing out from the left lateral epiglottis at the region consistent with its base although this was unclear for identification secondary to edema and it was possible that she may have had a lesion in this area . Lungs : Clear . Heart : Regular rate and rhythm . S1 and S2 , no murmurs , rubs or gallops . Abdomen : Soft , nontender , positive bowel sounds , no hepatosplenomegaly , no bruits . Extremities : Normal . Showed significant thoracic kiphosis . Due to the marked amount of edema , it was felt that she should go the Operating Room emergently for elective intubation . The patient was sedated . Direct laryngoscopy was performed but this revealed only a large amount of base of tongue edema with minimally visible epiglottis which was also significantly edematous and no distinct xxxPEOPLExxx or lesion could be noted . She was transferred to the SICU where she was kept sedated and was given Ceftriaxone one gram q. xxxxADDRESS7xxxx down to the Operating Room . Her episode of atrial fibrillation as we planned to take her from the Operating Room after both the intubation and central line placement had been completed . She continued in normal sinus rhythm and was transferred to the ICU where she was monitored . Her blood gases and O2 saturations correlated well and we used O2 saturations to follow her as well as venous gases and she continued to maintain good O2 saturation . She was kept ventilated because she was kept sedated . She continued in sinus rhythm after this episode of SVT and again had no problems with her blood pressure during that . Her edema decreased over the next xxxxWRITTEN_AGE_1_TO_19xxxx and repeat fiberoptic examination on both <PHI TYPE="DATE xxxxDATE22xxxx PHI> and <PHI TYPE="DATE xxxxDATE22xxxx PHI> revealed decreasing edema . On <PHI TYPE="DATE" xxxxDATE22xxxx /PHI>/91 in the ICU under controlled conditions , she was electively extubated and had no problems . She was kept on Ceftriaxone but no further steroids were given . Examination at that time revealed question of a lesion at the left lateral glossoepiglottic fold . Of note , during her xxxPEOPLExxx hospital day when she received steroids her blood sugars did increase significantly and therefore she was started on insulin . Tube feedings were started on <PHI TYPE="DATE xxxxDATE22xxxx PHI>/91 and the xxxPEOPLExxx tube was discontinued on <PHI TYPE="DATE" xxxxDATE22xxxx /PHI>/91 prior to extubation to give a better look at the epiglottis prior to extubating her . Again , MI was ruled out and metabolic tests were within normal limits . It was felt that this was a mild episode of ICU psychosis . She was followed on the regular floor 24 hours after extubation and had no further problems with her airway . She was maintained on Ceftriaxone and then switched to Augmentin and remained afebrile . She had a geriatric consult due to her confusion and they suggested as we had already done to stop all sedatives and sleeping medications . Cardiology was contacted and recommended that given her history she should be taken off all Digoxin and just watched and that her SVTs may have been just secondary to stress of intubation . Unfortunately the episodes of atrial fibrillation and SVT were apparently not documented well enough in terms of EKG strips to aid Cardiology and therefore , they gave us an informal consult so that no formal consult will be found in this chart . Nonetheless , their input was greatly appreciated and she was taken off of Digoxin and had no further problems with her heart . DISPOSITION : She , of note , had no history of foreign body ingestion or any abrasion or trauma to this area . If she does have a lesion , then we may entertain , given her age , the possibility of radiating this lesion as opposed to putting her through laryngectomy . The patient is to followup in the ENT Clinic in approximately xxxxWRITTEN_AGE_1_TO_19xxxx EPIGLOTTITIS , QUESTION SECONDARY TO EPIGLOTTIC MALIGNANCY . <TEXT> <PHI TYPE="ID xxxxSUSPICIOUS_NUMxxxx 260z</PHI> <PHI TYPE="ID xxxxSUSPICIOUS_NUMxxxx PHI> <PHI TYPE="DATE xxxxDATE21xxxx PHI xxxxYEAR_CENTURYxxxx 12:00:00 AM CHOLANGIOCARCINOMA , RECURRENT ; STATUS POST RADIATION DIS Report Status : ADMISSION DATE : <PHI TYPE="DATE xxxxDATE21xxxx PHI>/95 DISCHARGE DATE : <PHI TYPE="DATE xxxxDATE4xxxx PHI>/95 PRINCIPAL DIAGNOSIS : Cholangiocarcinoma , recurrent ; status post radiation therapy and chemotherapy . On <PHI TYPE="DATE xxxxDATE21xxxx PHI>/95 , replacement of permanent biliary stents and liver biopsy . OTHER PROCEDURES : On <PHI TYPE="DATE xxxxDATE21xxxx PHI>/95 , percutaneous transhepatic cholangiogram . In <PHI TYPE="DATE xxxxMONTHxxxx PHI> xxxxYEAR_CENTURYxxxx , he had an endoscopic retrograde cholangiopancreatography that shoed obstruction at the confluence of the left and xxxPEOPLExxx hepatic ducts . He was admitted in <PHI TYPE="DATE xxxxMONTHxxxx PHI> xxxxYEAR_CENTURYxxxx , for biliary drainage catheter placement and balloon dilatation of what was thought to be an anastomotic stricture . Biopsies and fine needle aspirates were suspicious for recurrent cholangiocarcinoma . He presented now for evaluation of failed biliary drainage . PHYSICAL EXAMINATION : On physical examination , he had a normal temperature and blood pressure . The extremities were unremarkable . Rectal examination was negative and his neurological examination was intact . His hematocrit was 25.8% , with a normal white blood cell count . <TEXT> <PHI TYPE="HOSPITAL">PUOMC</PHI> <PHI TYPE="ID xxxxTELEPHONE1xxxx PHI> Unsigned DISCHARGE DATE : <PHI TYPE="DATE">05-26</PHI>-94 CHIEF COMPLAINT : <PHI TYPE="PATIENT">Cean Leach</PHI> is a xxxxAGE5xxxx who is admitted in transfer from the <PHI TYPE="HOSPITAL">Morehegron Valley Hospital</PHI> in <PHI TYPE="LOCATION">Ville , Virginia</PHI> for further evaluation and management of accelerating chest pains syndrome . Mr. <PHI TYPE="PATIENT">Leach</PHI> has a long and complex history of coronary artery disease . A subsequent cardiac catheterization revealed a 90% lesion in his proximal left anterior descending coronary artery and minor disease elsewhere in his coronary distribution . His ejection xxxPEOPLExxx was in the mid-50's. Because of angina following that catheterization , he ultimately underwent percutaneous transluminal coronary angioplasty of his left anterior descending coronary artery . He did well until he developed recurrent angina in <PHI TYPE="DATE xxxxMONTHxxxx PHI> of xxxxYEAR_CENTURYxxxx at which time repeat catheterization demonstrated restenosis of his left anterior descending and he underwent a second PTCA with good results . Since that time , he has had multiple admissions to <PHI TYPE="HOSPITAL">George'sdgot Medical Center</PHI> with recurrent chest pain . He has had a progressive decline in his left ventricular ejection xxxPEOPLExxx as measured by non invasive means with an echo ejection xxxPEOPLExxx in the low 40's and radionuclide ejection xxxPEOPLExxx estimated in <PHI TYPE="DATE xxxxMONTHxxxx PHI> of xxxxYEAR_CENTURYxxxx at 31% . He was admitted to <PHI TYPE="HOSPITAL">George'sdgot Medical Center</PHI> with a typical episode of this discomfort in <PHI TYPE="DATE xxxxMONTHxxxx PHI> of xxxxYEAR_CENTURYxxxx . He was transferred at that time to the <PHI TYPE="HOSPITAL">Ph xxxxPRIVATExxx Of Medical Center</PHI> . That was his xxxPEOPLExxx <PHI TYPE="HOSPITAL">Ph xxxxPRIVATExxx Of Medical Center</PHI> admission . Because of Mr. <PHI TYPE="PATIENT">Leach</PHI> 's history and the fact that multiple cardiac catheterizations prior to that transfer had failed to demonstrate fixed epicardial coronary disease , it was decided that he should undergo provocative testing to evaluate whether or not he had coronary artery spasm and / or impaired coronary flow reserve . He was taken to the Catheter Laboratory on <PHI TYPE="DATE xxxxDATE7xxxx PHI> , xxxxYEAR_CENTURYxxxx . There he had a xxxPEOPLExxx heart catheterization with unremarkable intercardiac pressures . Repeat coronary angiography once again failed to demonstrate any significant obstructive lesions in either his dominant xxxPEOPLExxx coronary artery or his left coronary system . However , he did develop typical anginal discomfort which was easily reversed with intracoronary nitroglycerin . It was felt that the time that this study was most consistent with a syndrome of impaired coronary flow reserve or microvascular angina . Starting in the <PHI TYPE="DATE xxxxMONTHxxxx PHI> of xxxxYEAR_CENTURYxxxx , he once again started having recurrences of his typical anginal discomfort . He had a prolonged episode of typical anginal pain and xxxPEOPLExxx in for a small Q wave myocardial infarction . His medications that had been used individually or in combination include beta blockers and Lodapine cardiazem , nifidepine and coumadin , aspirin , cyclopadine and seratonin antagonists . There is no history of drug abuse or smoking . Of note , his brother had a myocardial infarction in his late 20's . PHYSICAL EXAMINATION : He looked generally well . His heart rate was xxxxADDRESS8xxxx abdomen was obese with no palpable organomegaly . His femoral pulses were l+ and equal without bruits . Potassium of 3 xxxxADDRESS8xxxx BUN was 12 and his creatinine was 1 xxxxADDRESS8xxxx was l55 although subsequent determinations were normal . His fasting cholesterol was 174 with an HDL of 35 and an LDH of xxxxADDRESS8xxxx liver function tests were normal with the exception of his LDH which was mildly elevated to xxxxADDRESS8xxxx hematocrit was approximately 39 with an unremarkable differential and normal platelet count . HOSPITAL COURSE : the primary concern upon Mr. <PHI TYPE="PATIENT">Leach</PHI> 's transfer was that despite the fact that he had multiple previous catheterizations over the prior xxxxWRITTEN_AGE_1_TO_19xxxx that he may have redeveloped obstructive coronary artery disease . The left ventricular pressure was l05 xxxxADDRESS8xxxx angiography revealed a picture which was essentially unchanged from <PHI TYPE="DATE xxxxMONTHxxxx PHI> of xxxxYEAR_CENTURYxxxx . Left ventriculography revealed a large area of antero lateral and apical hypokinesis to akinesis with an estimated ejection xxxPEOPLExxx of 35% . Impression at the time of his catheterization was that the precise etiology of his chest pain remained rather enigmatic . He was ; therefore , xxxPEOPLExxx in consultation by Dr. <PHI TYPE="DOCTOR">Lato Tikfreierm</PHI> of the Hematology Service to evaluate him further for a possible hypocoagulable condition versus primary and secondary platelet abnormality which could explain his recurrent coronary events . Specifically , his platelets were not affected by aspirin and showed spontaneous hyperaggragability . This was utilized in making some changes in Mr. <PHI TYPE="PATIENT">Leach</PHI> 's regiment . Specifically his aspirin was discontinued and he was put back on ticlopidine at a higher than ordinary dose at 500 mg. b.i.d. Repeat in xxxNAMExxx testing of Mr. <PHI TYPE="PATIENT">Leach</PHI> 's platelets suggested that although they remained refractory to aspirin , they did demonstrate reduced hyperaggragability spontaneously which was felt to be possible reflective of the ticlopidine effect . While in the hospital , Mr. <PHI TYPE="PATIENT">Leach</PHI> continued to nearly daily episodes of chest pain . These were generally spontaneous in nature and lasted anywhere from several minutes to nearly an hour duration . There were typically improved but not completely eradicated with sublingual nitroglycerin and generally required i.v. narcotics for complete pain relief . Multiple changes and additions were made to his drug regimen . He was tried on a variety of different combinations of calcium channel blockers including amlodipine and diltiazem and lodipine and verapamil . Amlodipine and bepridil all without marked change in his clinical syndrome . The rest of his hypercoagulable work up revealed that he had nearly normal xxxPEOPLExxx of clotting factors , specifically , his antithrombin 3 of level was lll with a reference range of xxxxSUSPICIOUS_NUM2xxxx . Protein S was l14 with a reference range of xxxxSUSPICIOUS_NUM2xxxx . Plasminogen was slightly high at l51 with upper limit of normal being l30 . xxxPEOPLExxx 8 was likewise slightly high at 249 with a reference range of xxxxSUSPICIOUS_NUM2xxxx . Thrombin time and repalase time were normal . It was felt that these results were non specific and may represent just an acute phase reactants . His anti cardio lipen antibodies both IGM and IGG were within normal range . His APC resistance was normal . Rheumatology felt that there was no good evidence of a primary vasculitic process as the source of his presumed small xxxNAMExxx coronary disease and no further rheumatologic work up was undertaken . He had multiple 24 hour urine tests performed to evaluate the question of theochromocytoma , these demonstrated mild elevations of some urinary catacholomines , but it was felt that this could well represent a reaction to the complex medical regimen that he was having as well as the recurrent episodes of pain themselves . His compliment xxxPEOPLExxx were normal and he had no evidence of hepatitis , B serologies which also measured to see if there was some chronic inflammatory process . To evaluate the efficacy of this prior to commiting him to a permanent blockade procedure , a temporary sympathetic blockade was performed using a local anesthetic and stellate ganglion injection . He was then taken directly from the pain clinic to the exercise laboratory and repeat exercise testing was done . After extensive discussions with the patient , the pain service and thoracic surgery , it was felt appropriate to proceed with a surgical sympathectomy to relieve him of his intractable chest pain syndrome . Therefore , on <PHI TYPE="DATE xxxxDATE7xxxx PHI> , the patient underwent left thorascopic thoracic sympathectomy by Dr. <PHI TYPE="DOCTOR">Aalv Sctroi</PHI> . He tolerated that procedure well and had no recurrent anginal pain throughout the rest of his hospitalization . DISCHARGE MEDICATIONS : Ticlopodine 500 mg. p.o.b.i.d. Lovastatin 20 mg. p.o.q.d. Lasix 80 mg. q.d. Kayciel 60 meq b.i.d. Cimetidine 400 mg. b.i.d. Isordil 20 mg. t.i.d. and Lodopine 10 mg. q.d. a combination of Percocet , Morphine Sulfate elixir xxxPEOPLExxx as needed . Left stellate ganglion sympathetic block on <PHI TYPE="DATE xxxxDATE21xxxx PHI>/94 and placement of a low catheter with sympathetic block on <PHI TYPE="DATE xxxxDATE7xxxx PHI> . <PHI TYPE="DOCTOR">TRI I.
